lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters, sports, and instruments mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before listening, preview instruments and sports in the SB. Ask students to raise their hands when they hear each item during the story.
stretchStrategies: Students retell or act out the story, then each student adds one sentence to continue the story using a sport or instrument. Encourage them to use full questions and answers with correct auxiliary verbs from Lessons 1–2.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read the story aloud in short sections. Students echo each line. Assign roles and act it out using props or mime.
stretchStrategies: Students retell or act out the story, then each student adds one sentence to continue the story using a sport or instrument. Encourage them to use full questions and answers with correct auxiliary verbs from Lessons 1–2.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or acting it out.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Ask: “What if the story had one more scene?” Students create their own ending using speech bubbles or short performance.
stretchStrategies: Students retell or act out the story, then each student adds one sentence to continue the story using a sport or instrument. Encourage them to use full questions and answers with correct auxiliary verbs from Lessons 1–2.

items: Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
Con không thích >> I no/not like [I don't like]
Playground words tend to be long and phonetically difficult (slide, see-saw, swings, climbing frame)
Some sports not well known in VN (baseball, cricket, rugby, paragliding, water skiing)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.
